https://studio.code.org/s/csd2-2023/less.long_instructions: _This level follows a video that you may have watched with your class. If you missed the video, you can watch it in the Help and Tips tab of this level._ # Welcome to Web Lab! The platform you are in is called Web Lab. There are three main parts of the screen in Web Lab. In this level, let's get to know our partner for pair programming. # Do This **Driver:** 1. Type the name of your Navigator, their favorite color, and their favorite animal on different lines in the workspace. - ::: details [**Show Me How**] ::: 2. Press to see it in the preview area! Does the preview match how you typed it in the workspace?
https://studio.code.org/s/csd2-2023/less.teacher_markdown: After giving students some time to explore the tool, ask them to share out anything that they have discovered.  The video on the next level will give them a short tour, so it's okay if they don't notice everything.

https://studio.code.org/s/csd2-2023/less.long_instructions: _This level follows a video that you may have watched with your class. If you missed the video, you can watch it in the Help and Tips tab of this level._ # Explore HTML This is a web page written in HTML, the language of the web. You'll learn more about how it works, but first explore it by using the Inspector Tool. # Do This 1. Click on the Inspector Tool . _You will know that the Inspector Tool is on because the button will say "Inspector: On" and lines of code will highlight when hover over content._ 2. Once you turn on the Inspector Tool, you can hover over anything in the preview area and Web Lab will highlight the code that is making that part of the page appear. Notice that some parts of the code have special `< >` markers surrounding the words 3. **With your Navigator:** Use the inspector tool and try to determine which `< >` code create the following effects on the website: - What code makes the text bigger and bolder? - What code makes text appear as a list? - What code makes the text appear on separate lines? - What's a piece of code that doesn't appear to do anything on the screen?

_This level follows a video that you may have watched with your class. If you missed the video, you can watch it in the Help and Tips tab of this level._ # Add Text to the Body When you start any Web Lab project, it will automatically add ``, ``, ``, and `` tags to your project. When you add content to your projects, you'll need to do it between the `` and `` tags because it should be part of the body of your webpage. Another student, Sofia, has already started adding text to her webpage. She started to add paragraph tags so each sentence would appear on its own line, but hasn't finished # Do This 1. Finish adding `

` and `

` tags to Sofia's code so each sentence appears on a separate line 2. Use the Inspector tool to verify that each line appears on its own ::: details [**Show Me How**] **More resources are in the "Help and Tips" tab** ::: [][0]

# Use Paragraph Tags The `

` `

` tags or "paragraph" start and end tags are placed around text to indicate that it is part of a paragraph. Placing text between paragraph start and end tags lets the computer know that it should be treated differently, often just spacing it out from other text. # Do This 1. Click in between the `` and `` tags - this is where you'll add your code 2. Create two paragraphs that ask a question and answer it. This can be a trivia question, a riddle, or a joke. - For example: "What continent has the largest land mass?" - "Asia" 3. Place the text you just wrote inside two separate paragraphs by surrounding each line with `

` and `

` tags

One person should add the "fortunately" sentences, and the other person should add the "unfortunately" sentences - Be sure to use `

` and `

` tags so each line of the story appears as a separate line - Repeat this until the story is at least 8 lines long

https://studio.code.org/s/csd2-2023/less.long_instructions:
# Explore Heading Tags

HTML defines six levels of headings, and these heading elements are H1, H2, H3, H4, H5, and H6. The H1 element is the highest or most important level, and the H6 element is the least important.

These different heading levels help to communicate the organization and hierarchy of the content on a page. For example, headings with an equal or higher ranking indicate the start of a new section, and headings with a lower rank indicate the start of a new subsection that is part of a higher-ranked section.

# Do This

1.  Turn on the Inspector Tool.
2.  Hover over each of the bold headings on the web page to find out which heading size was used.
3.  Discuss with your partner:
    -   When would you use each of these headings?
        -   For example, which heading would you use for a web page title ... when might you use the H6 heading?

# Headings So far, you've organized your content into paragraphs. Another way HTML allows you to organize your code is by using **headings**. A heading is a short piece of text that goes at the top of a section of content, like a title. # Do This: 1. Find the headings in the web page below and use the Inspector Tool to see the code that makes them. 2. Make sure you and your partner agree on what the tags do. 3. Change the code so that "Drawing" and "2 years" match the headings on the rest of the page. ::: details [**Show Me How**] **More resources are in the "Help and Tips" tab** ::: [][0]

# Heading Sizes Headings can come in different sizes. In this page, there are six different sized headings, but they are all mixed up. Can you and your partner figure out how to fix them? # Do This: 1. Use the inspector tool to figure out what makes the headings different sizes 2. Make sure you and your partner agree on what the different heading tags do. 3. Change the tags so that the headings are in order from biggest to smallest, and the text says the correct size, as in the picture to the right. ::: details [**Show Me How To Get Started**] **More resources are in the "Help and Tips" tab** ::: [][0]

https://studio.code.org/s/csd2-2023/less.long_instructions:
# Unordered Lists There are two types of lists in HTML, ordered and unordered lists. An **unordered list** is just a set of _bulleted_ items.

An unordered list element has the tag `
    `. This is an abbreviation for Unordered List. Each item in the list is marked by a list item element `
  • `. This is an abbreviation for List Item. The list item element is a child element, which means that it goes **_inside_** of its parent element, the unordered list (`
      `). Take a look at how the given code below creates an unordered list. Pay special attention to the whitespace and indentation of the `
    • `. # Do This 1. Look at how the `
        ` and `
      • ` tags are used to create an unordered list. 2. Use the `
          ` and `
        • ` tags to create your own dessert list. ::: details [**Show me another example of working code.**]
          Example Result
          • Red
          • Green
          • Blue

          **More resources are in the "Help and Tips" tab** :::

https://studio.code.org/s/csd2-2023/less.bubble_choice_description: Use the <ol> tag to create a numbered list
https://studio.code.org/s/csd2-2023/less.long_instructions:
# Ordered Lists An ordered list is like an unordered (bulleted) list, but it has numbers. Just use the `
    ` tag instead of `
      `. This is an abbreviation for Ordered List. Just like your bulleted list, each item in the ordered (numbered) list is marked by a list item element `
    • `;. This is an abbreviation for List Item. The list item element is a child element, which means that it goes **_inside_** of its parent element, the ordered list (`
        `). # Do This 1. Use the `
          ` and `
        1. ` tags to structure this content into an ordered list. ::: details [**Show me an example of working code.**]
          Example Result
          1. Step 1
          2. Step 2
          3. Step 3

          **More resources are in the "Help and Tips" tab** :::
          ::: details [**Show Me How To Complete This Level**]

          **More resources are in the "Help and Tips" tab** :::

mini_rubric.rubric_key_concept:
Use HTML to create a web page that includes hierarchical headings, paragraphs, lists, and images.

Understand the need for precision when using computer languages and use appropriate syntax.
mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_1: All content is contained in tags, uses paragraph tags, multiple sized headings, and at least one list in a logically consistent way.
mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_2: All content is contained in tags, uses paragraph, heading tags, and a list in a reasonable way.
mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_3: Most content is contained in tags.  At least one heading tag is used.
mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_4: Little or no content is contained in tags.

CSD Web Headings line break_2023.bubble_choice_description: Learn how to make new lines without starting a new paragraph.  You can use this code to add poems or lists to your page.
CSD Web Headings line break_2023.long_instructions:
# Extra Code: Line Break In some situations, like a poem or a list, you'll want to start a new line inside the same paragraph, like you might do in poetry. You can use the line break `
` tag for this. # Do This 1) Read the HTML and look for where the line break `
` code is used to separate the lines in the poem. 2) Add two more line breaks to separate out the other lines in the poem. **Tip:** The `
` tag is useful for writing addresses or poems. **Note:** Use the `
` tag to enter line breaks, not to separate paragraphs. Always separate each paragraph with its own set of `

` and `

` tags!

CSD Web Headings hr_2023.bubble_choice_description: Learn the code for making a horizontal rule and practice using it.
CSD Web Headings hr_2023.long_instructions:
# Extra Code: Horizontal Rule

In some situations, you'll want to insert a horizontal line, or rule, to break up themes in your page. You can use the horizontal rule `<hr>` tag for this.

# Do This
1) Read the HTML and look for where the `<hr>` code is used to add a horizontal rule in the web page.
2) Add more horizontal rules to break up the page by theme.

CSD Web Headings Special Character 3_202.bubble_choice_description: Learn the code for the special character "&" and practice using it.
CSD Web Headings Special Character 3_202.long_instructions:
# Extra Code: Special Character "&" The ampersand character (**&**) can cause errors in your HTML code because it is actually used for other special characters like less than symbols (**<** is encoded as `<`), and double quotation marks (**"** is encoded as`"`). To use the **&** character in a paragraph correctly, you need the special code `&`. *Yes, you need an ampersand to encode an ampersand!*
In this activity, you'll make up a list some of your favorite things and practice using ampersands. # Do This 1) Read the HTML and look for where the `&` code is used correctly. * Replace the ampersand that is causing pink code with the special code for the symbol. * Fill in the blank categories or add your own using the new code. Try to come up with answers that use the symbol!

CSD Web Headings Free Play_2023.bubble_choice_description: Try using the new code you have learned to create your own HTML page about your favorite books.
CSD Web Headings Free Play_2023.long_instructions:
# Your Favorite Books

Now that you have learned how to create HTML headings, lists, and code special characters, you can put your skills to the test! 

# Do This
1) Create a web page about your favorite books!
	- For example, this web page could include information about your favorite genre of books and then a list of your top 3 favorites!
    - You could even do favorite books and use the horizontal rule tag to separate the descriptions of each one!
    
You may not be able to create the "perfect" web page just yet, but you can develop a **prototype** that shows your general idea!
CSD Web Headings Free Play_2023.teacher_markdown:
This level does not contain an exemplar because of how open-ended the directions are. Instead, we encourage you to consider this as a focused free-play level: students are free to design a web page based on their own interests and creative expression, but focused in a particular area to give some initial guidance. This can be an opportunity to gain insights and offer feedback on the skills students demonstrate while building their web page, even if they do not finish the level completely. This type of level can also reinforce the Problem Solving Process as students ideate and develop a web page of their own choosing (Define - Prepare - Try - Reflect).

As students develop more skills throughout the unit, they may decide to use an idea from this level as the basis for one of their projects or to continue developing on their own time.

You can make a new rule set by copying the pattern you see in the rule-set for the `h1` tag. # Do this 1. Find the CSS rule-set in the style sheet that determines the styles for the `h1` tag. 2. Using the same pattern, write a new CSS rule-set that will determine the style for the `h3` tag. 3. Add code to set a different color for the `h3` tags. ::: details [**Show Me How**]

1) Find the CSS rule-set in the style sheet that determines the style for the paragraph tag.

CSD U2 text style font family_2023.teacher_markdown:
## Note on fonts and font families

For a web browser to display a font, the font **must** be available on the device the web browser is running on.  There's no guarantee that any device has a particular font, so it's much safer to use font **families**, which allow for many different fonts that have the same general look at feel.

If students want to specify an exact font, they'll need to use a font from the web, so the browser can download that specific font to use when rendering the page.  More information on these fonts can be found at [Google Fonts](https://fonts.google.com/) and [W3Schools](https://www.w3schools.com/Css/css3_fonts.asp).

# Review your Page

Next, check to make sure your page has everything you want.

# Do This

1.  Check to make sure all the **content** is there.
2.  Check that the HTML tags **structure** the content correctly.
3.  Check that the CSS properties **style** the content correctly.
4.  Make sure your code is organized, readable and free of bugs.

# Explore Image Tags

Adding images to our web pages is a powerful skill that will make your pages more appealing to users!

An image tag consist of some new components, namely the **src** attribute and the **alt** attribute.

The **src** attribute stands for "source" and the value of this attribute will be the name of the image file you want on your web page.

The **alt** attribute stands for "alternate text" and the value should be a short descriptive word or two about the image. If an image does not load on a web page, it is this alternate text that will show up instead.

# Do This

1.  Turn on the Inspector Tool.
2.  Hover over the image on the web page to find the tag used.
3.  Discuss with your partner:
    -   How do you think they knew what the name of the image should be for the **src** (source) attribute? Where did they find this information here in Web Lab?
    -   What did they put as the alternate text? Do you think that is descriptive enough?
    -   What else do you notice about the image tag?

Add information about where the image came from and its license. *(This image was found at pixabay and was uploaded by the user "Alexas\_Fotos", who used a "free for commercial use" and "no attribution required" license.)* ::: details [**Show Me How**] **More resources are in the "Help and Tips" tab** :::

https://studio.code.org/s/csd2-2023/less.long_instructions:
# The Details Matter

The `src` attribute needs to point to the _exact_ filename of the image you want to use. That means you need to pay attention to spelling, capitalization, and the file extension. Each of the three images on this page is broken because of an improper `src` attribute. 

# Do This

1.  Using the file menu for reference, fix each of the image tags.
2.  When you are finished, each image should display correctly in the webpage preview.

_Note: Even though the images are not loading properly, our website is still showing descriptive text of what should be there because we used `alt` attributes. Cool!_

# Choosing a Good Name It's important for images to have good names, ones that are easy to understand and use characters that are good for links. This project's image names have some problems. # Do This 1. For each image, fix the name according to the following rules: - Avoid special characters such as `&`, `?`, `%`, `/`, `(`, etc. - Make sure the name has a specific meaning that helps you know what the image is. - Use dashes (`-`) or underscores (`_`) instead of spaces. - Keep the names as short as possible and still have a clear meaning. 2. Choose your favorite image and add it to the web page. - Don't forget the attribution! | Image | Amphibian | Attribution | | ----- | ------------------------------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | [][0] | **kani bushfrog** | Rison Thumboor - Wikimedia Commons - CC-BY-SA | | [][1] | **paedophryne amauensis** | Rittmeyer EN, Allison A, Grndler MC, Thompson DK, Austin CC - Wikimedia Commons - CC-BY | | [][2] | **red eyed tree frog** | Carey James Balboa - Wikimedia Commons - Public Domain | | [][3] | **fire salamander** | Cristo Vlahos - Wikimedia Commons - CC-BY | | [][4] | **axolotl** | th1098 - Wikimedia Commons - CC-BY-SA |

::: details [**Show Me How**] **More resources are in the "Help and Tips" tab** ::: [][5]

# Uploading Images You can upload images that you've found elsewhere using the **Add Image** button. Go find an image of a different type of pet that you like and download it to your computer (using right-click "Save As"). Once you have your images, click [][0] and upload the image from your computer into your project, where you can then use it in your page. # Do This 1. Find an image you are allowed to use and upload it to this project. 2. Make sure the file name follows your naming rules. 3. Use the `` tag to display the image(s) in your website. - Make sure to add an `alt` attribute! 4. Add the attribution information below the image. ::: details [**Show Me How to Upload**] **More resources are in the "Help and Tips" tab** ::: [][1]
https://studio.code.org/s/csd2-2023/less.teacher_markdown:
# Recommended Search Engines

Because we can't know which sites might be blocked in your district, we've avoided pointing students to a specific search engine. Not all search engines make it easy to set Creative Commons filters - some of the easiest include:

-   [Creative Commons Search][0]
-   [Google Image Advanced Search][1]
-   [Wikimedia Commons][2]
-   [Flickr Creative Commons][3]

As with any site with crowdsourced content, search engine results will change from day to day, and some of those results may be inappropriate for the classroom.  You may want to check these sites shortly before displaying them to the class, and decide what is best for your classroom.

# Layout and Style

# Do This

1.  Look through web page below for new styles.
2.  Open the style sheet
3.  With your partner, discuss which parts of the CSS code you think are making the page appear different.
    -   What makes the entire page blue?
    -   How are the images positioned to the left of all the other elements?

In the next few levels, you'll be changing and adding new styles on this page.

# Background Color # Do This 1. Find the code in the style sheet that is making the background of the entire page light blue. 2. Change the code to make the page a different color. 3. Try to change the background color of just the paragraphs. ::: details [**Show Me How**] **More resources are in the "Help and Tips" tab** ::: [][0]

# The Body Element

# Do This

1.  Find the `body` rule-set in the style sheet.
2.  Discuss with a partner what you think will happen if you add `text-align`, `color`, or other text properties to the `body` rule set.
3.  Try out some different properties to check your guesses.

# Float

# Do This

1.  Look at the `float` property inside your `img` rule-set
2.  Discuss with your partner what you think the property does.
3.  Change the value from `left` to `right`.

# Width and Height

# Do This

1.  Find the property in the style sheet that controls the width of the images.
2.  Change the width of the images to be larger or smaller.
3.  Create a new rule with a `height` property to control the height of the images.
4.  Use the `width` property in the `p` rule-set to change the width of your paragraphs.

dsls.description: Try extra challenges or learn some new code.

CSD U2 layout style border_2023.bubble_choice_description: Create borders around the elements on your page.
CSD U2 layout style border_2023.long_instructions:
::: details [**What colors can I use in CSS?**] CSS includes most common color names (red, blue, green, etc.), and many uncommon ones. You can see a full list of CSS color names at W3Schools - HTML Color Names. You can still use colors that are not included in the named list, but you will need to use their RGB values. You can read more about using colors in CSS at W3Schools - CSS Legal Color Values ::: ::: details [**How does the code work?**] Here is the code that is making the image borders: ``` img { border-color: saddlebrown; border-width: 4px; border-style: solid; border-radius: 10px; } ``` * `img` is the _selector_. It specifies which elements will have to follow the rules inside the curly braces, in this case, the images. * `border-color: saddlebrown;`,`border-width: 4px;`,`border-style: solid;`, and `border-radius: 10px;` are the rules that make the border. ::: ::: details [**What does the `border-style` property do?**] The `border-style` property determines what kind of border (solid, dotted, etc.) the element has. You can read more about this property at W3Schools - CSS border-style Property ::: ::: details [**What does the `border-radius` property do?**] The `border-radius` property determines the radius of the curves at the corners of the element. A bigger radius makes a bigger, softer curve, and a smaller radius makes a smaller, sharper curve. A radius of zero makes a regular corner. You can read more about this property at W3Schools - CSS3 border-radius property ::: ::: details [**What does the `float` property do?**] The `float` property makes an element "float", meaning that the elements that come after it all flow around it. If the `float` value is `left`, the element will float to the left, and the elements after it will show up on its right. If the `float` value is `right`, the element will float to the right, and the elements after it will show up on its left. You can read more about this property at W3Schools - CSS float Property :::
# Borders * Find the rules in the style sheet that set image borders color and width. * Change the color and width of your borders. * Try out some different border styles. * Choose from `dotted`, `dashed`, `solid`, and `double` * Put a border on another type of page element, such as one of the headings or the paragraphs.

CSD U2 layout style borderradius_2023.bubble_choice_description: Make the corners of your images rounded.
CSD U2 layout style borderradius_2023.long_instructions:
::: details [**How does the code work?**] Here is the code that is making the image borders: ``` img { border-color: saddlebrown; border-width: 4px; border-style: solid; border-radius: 10px; } ``` * `img` is the _selector_. It specifies which elements will have to follow the rules inside the curly braces, in this case, the images. * `border-color: saddlebrown;`,`border-width: 4px;`,`border-style: solid;`, and `border-radius: 10px;` are the rules that make the border. ::: ::: details [**What does the `border-style` property do?**] The `border-style` property determines what kind of border (solid, dotted, etc.) the element has. You can read more about this property at W3Schools - CSS border-style Property ::: ::: details [**What does the `border-radius` property do?**] The `border-radius` property determines the radius of the curves at the corners of the element. A bigger radius makes a bigger, softer curve, and a smaller radius makes a smaller, sharper curve. A radius of zero makes a regular corner. You can read more about this property at W3Schools - CSS3 border-radius property ::: ::: details [**What does the `float` property do?**] The `float` property makes an element "float", meaning that the elements that come after it all flow around it. If the `float` value is `left`, the element will float to the left, and the elements after it will show up on its right. If the `float` value is `right`, the element will float to the right, and the elements after it will show up on its left. You can read more about this property at W3Schools - CSS float Property :::
# Border Radius * Look at the `border-radius` property inside your `img` rule-set * Discuss with your partner what you think the property does. * Try different values for border radius and decide which one you like the best.

CSD U2 layout style margin_2023.bubble_choice_description: Control the amount of space around each element in your page.
CSD U2 layout style margin_2023.long_instructions:
::: details [**How does the code work?**] Here is the code that is putting extra space around the images: img { margin: 10px; } * `img` is the _selector_. It specifies which elements will have to follow the rules inside the curly braces, in this case, the images. * `margin: 10px;` is the rule that puts 10 pixels of space around the image. ::: ::: details [**What does the `margin` property do?**] The `margin` property determines how much space will be around the image. Most of the time, you will define in the margin in pixels. You can read more about this property at W3Schools - CSS margin Property ::: ::: details [**What does `px` mean / What is a pixel?**] Pixel, which is abbreviated `px`, is how elements are measured in CSS. Its the size of a single point of light on the screen. :::
# Margin Margins specify how much space should be around an element. * Find the `margin` property in the `img` rule-set. * Change the margin to be larger, and discuss the effect with a partner. * Choose another element type and give it a margin, too.

dsls.markdown:
# Your Personal Web Page In the next few levels, you'll be completing and publishing your personal web page. This is your chance to share your ideas with the world, and also to show all the things that you have learned. You'll need... * Your completed project guide * The images you downloaded * The project rubric Here are the things you have learned... * How to use HTML to structure the content of your page * How to use CSS to style the text, colors, and layout of your page * How to format your code to make it easier to read * How to debug HTML and CSS code * How to use use images in a responsible way * How to protect your personal information online ## Examples
The Cutest Dog
My Trip
Musical Instruments
Recycling Club
Haikus

https://studio.code.org/s/csd2-2023/less.long_instructions:
# Upload Images

Next, you'll need to upload all of your images into your project.

# Do This

1.  Upload all of the images listed in your project guide into your project.
2.  Make sure each image file name uses good naming conventions

# Add HTML

Next, you should add the HTML to your page.

# Do This

1.  Add HTML to make the page you sketched in your project guide.
2.  Double check that the page has everything you want, and make any changes you need.

# Add Styles

Next, style the page according to your plan.

# Do This

1.  In the stylesheet, add CSS rule sets for your tags.
2.  Check to make sure that the page looks right, then make any adjustments

# Review Your Project

You're almost ready to publish your project, but you should check one more time that you have fulfilled all the requirements for this project.

# Do This

1.  Check that you are comfortable sharing all the information that's on your site.
2.  Check that all of your images are correctly attributed, and that you have the right to put them on your site.
3.  Check that your project includes everything included in the project rubric.
4.  Use comments and whitespace to make your website readable.
5.  Ask a classmate to help you find any potential problems with your site.

_This level follows a video that you may have watched with your class. If you missed the video, you can watch it in the Help and Tips tab of this level._

# Share Your Project

It's time to share your project with the world!

# Do This

1.  Click the [][0] button at the top of this page.
2.  Copy the URL it gives you, and email it to the people you want to see your page.

# Upload Images

Upload all of your team's images into your project.

# Do This

1.  Upload all of the images listed in your team's web site plan into your project.
2.  Double check that each image file name uses good naming conventions.
3.  Double check that everyone on the team has the exact same images with the exact same names.

# Making a Multi-page Site

A web site should include more than one web page, and they should connect to each other.   Here's an example of a project with multiple pages that are connected by hyperlinks (the blue underlined words that take you to another page when you click on them).

# Do This

1.  Use the inspector tool to see the code that creates the hyperlinks on the top of index.html.
2.  Discuss with your partner how you think that code works.

# Adding Links This page is almost working, but one of the pages is not linked. # Do This 1. Look at the working links and see how they work. 2. Add code that will link from the index page to the Charles Bridge page. 3. Add code that will link the Charles Bridge page to the index page. ::: details [**Show Me How**]
**More resources in the "Help and Tips" tab** ::: [][0]

# Naming Links

Just like images and files, links should have clear names that help someone understand what page they are linked to.

# Do This

1.  Read the code or click on the links to see where they go.
2.  Change the names of the links to make it clear where they will take you.

# Naming New Pages

You'll need to follow the same rules for naming html pages that you did for naming images.  This page has some problems caused by poorly named HTML files.

# Do This

1.  Click on the links in "index.html" and see which ones are broken.
2.  Change the file names and link `href` attributes so that they follow good naming conventions such as:
    -   Avoid special characters such as `&`, `?`, `%`, `/`, etc.
    -   Make sure the name has a specific meaning that helps you know what the page is
    -   Use dashes (`-`) or underscores (`_`) instead of spaces.
    -   Keep the names as short as possible and still have a clear meaning.

# Adding New Pages

To make your multi-page website, you'll need to add multiple pages to your project. To practice, let's split the content on this sample page into two pages and link them together.

# Do This

1.  Add a new HTML file by clicking  [][0].  The new file will appear in the files list on the left side of the workspace.
2.  Rename the file, either by right clicking it and choosing "Rename", or by clicking on it when it's already highlighted.  **Make sure the name is unique, descriptive and ends in ".html"**.
3.  Use HTML to fill out your new page. (You can use content from the main page.)
4.  Link to your new page from "index.html"
5.  Link back to the index from your new page.

mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_3: There is an `<a>` tag, but syntax errors or problems with the page name may prevent it from working
mini_rubric.rubric_performance_level_4: No new page was created and there are no links

CSD U2 external links_2023.bubble_choice_description: Link to other people's pages on the World Wide Web.
CSD U2 external links_2023.long_instructions:
# Linking External Pages


You can also make links that lead to other websites like Google using the `<a>` tag.

# Do this:
1) Look at the code that links to Google and see how it works
* Link your favorite websites and tell us why you like them!

CSD U2 image links_2023.long_instructions: # Images as Links You have learned that the text you type between the `` and `` tags is what the visitors to your page will see and click on when using links. You can actually add other tags and content, such as images, to this space in your code as well. # Do this: 1) Look at the code that makes the first two images on the `index.html` page into links. * Use that same code pattern to turn the second two images into links, too.

CSD U2 links buttons_2023.bubble_choice_description: Learn how to style hyperlinks to make them look like buttons
CSD U2 links buttons_2023.long_instructions: # Button Links Take a look at the image below of the five hyperlinks that have been styled to look like buttons. Can you figure out what properties and values you will need to use to make the links look like this? # Do This 1) Find the CSS rule for hyperlinks in your stylesheet. 2) Add the following properties to the hyperlink rule-set with values of your choice: * border-style * border-color * border-radius * padding * text-decoration * *Select "none" for this property* 3) Add the optional properties to the hyperlink rule-set with values of your choice to make the buttons more visually appealing: * background-color * color

https://studio.code.org/s/csd2-2023/less.long_instructions:
# Your Group Project

Here is your group project.  It already has an index page, but you'll need to create all of the other pages.

# Do This

1.  Double check all of the page names in your website plan to make sure they follow good naming conventions.
    -   Check with the rest of your group if you need to change a page name.
2.  Create a new page for each of the pages in your website plan.
3.  Inside each new page, create a temporary paragraph tag that describes the page and who is in charge of it.
4.  Check to make sure everyone in your group has the exact same list of HTML pages.

# Add Your Content and HTML

Now add all of the HTML you will need for your project, including links to the stylesheet and other pages.

If you are responsible for the navigation bar, add it here, too.

# Do This

1.  Add HTML to the pages.
2.  Test your links to make sure that they work.
3.  Check that all of your images are displaying.

# Share Your Content and HTML

Share your web page with your teammates, and copy and paste the code for their pages into your project.

# Do This

1.  "Share" your page, and give the link to your teammates.
2.  Get the "Share" link from each of your teammates and click the "View Code" link at the bottom of the screen.
3.  Copy the HTML from your teammates' pages into your project.
4.  Copy and paste the correct navigation bar onto each page.
5.  Check that all of the links and images work correctly.

# Add Your Styles

Now add all of the CSS you are responsible for, including your classes.

# Do This

1.  Add CSS rule sets to the stylesheet.
2.  Check that all of your pages are displaying the correct styles.

# Share Your Styles

Now share all of the CSS styles and classes with your teammates.

# Do This

1.  Use the "Share" link from each of your teammates and click "View Code" to see their HTML and CSS.
2.  Open each of your teammates' stylesheets and copy and paste their code into your stylesheet.
3.  Check the stylesheet to make sure that there are no conflicts (two rule sets for the same tag or style).
4.  Check that all of your pages are displaying the correct styles.

# Check Your Work

Your site is done!  Check to make sure it meets the requirements.

# Do This

1.  Check that your site looks the same as your teammates' sites.
2.  Check that your site includes everything from the project guide.
3.  Check that your site meets the requirements of the project in the rubric.

# Use Feedback

Now it's time to use the peer feedback to make your site even better.

# Do This

1.  Use the plan that your team came up with to improve your website.

In CSS files, rules are found inside curly braces `{}` and each rule consists of a property name and a value, separated by a colon `:`. HTML tags use `<>`.

CSD U2 FR Q1_2023.long_instructions: What is the purpose of copyright?
CSD U2 FR Q1_2023.teacher_markdown:
**Content: Unit 2 Lesson 8**

Copyright is intended to protect the rights of content creators. These rights include being recognized as the creator when the work is displayed, or deciding who can use and make money off the work.
